Utterance: Hi again! It’s great to see you back. How have you been since our last session?
Oh, you know, just the usual. Not much has changed.
I see. Last time, we talked about your living situation and how you feel about having roommates. Have you had any thoughts about that since we last spoke?
Yeah, it still sucks. I just need my own place, you know?
That sounds frustrating. Have you considered any steps towards finding your own space?
Not really. I mean, it’s expensive here. I can barely afford what I have.
That’s understandable. It can be tough in such a high-cost area. What do you think would help you feel more at ease in your current situation?
I guess just more alone time. I wish I could just lock myself in a room sometimes.
That makes sense. Have you found any ways to carve out that alone time?
A little. I just try to be out when they’re around, but it’s not always possible.
It sounds like you’re doing what you can. Speaking of alone time, you mentioned enjoying music on vinyl last time. Have you had any opportunities to listen to music lately?
Yeah, I’ve been digging into my collection a bit more. It’s relaxing.
That’s wonderful! What kind of music have you been enjoying?
Mostly classic rock, some punk. Just things that take me back, you know?
Nostalgia can be a powerful feeling. How does that music make you feel?
It just feels good. Like a time capsule, I guess.
That’s a beautiful way to describe it. Do you think music helps improve your mood when you’re feeling down?
Definitely. It’s like an escape.
That’s great to hear. Have you noticed any specific times when music has helped you recently?
Yeah, I was feeling kind of low last week, and I put on some old albums. It helped a lot.
I’m glad to hear that. It sounds like you have a healthy coping mechanism. Have you thought about other activities that could help lift your spirits?
Maybe. I used to like drawing, but I haven’t done that in a while.
Drawing can be a wonderful outlet. What do you think has stopped you from picking it up again?
I don’t know. Just lost interest, I guess.
That’s understandable. Sometimes interests shift. What if we set a small goal for you to try drawing again this week?
I could try. It might be nice to get back into it.
That sounds like a positive step! How about setting aside just 10-15 minutes a few times this week to doodle or sketch?
Yeah, I can do that.
Great! I’m looking forward to hearing how it goes. You mentioned feeling down sometimes. Are there specific triggers that you’ve noticed?
Just the usual stuff. Work, living situation, not having friends around.
Those are valid concerns. Have you thought about ways to connect with others, even if it’s just online?
I’ve tried, but it’s hard to find people I click with.
That makes sense. It’s important to find the right fit. Would you be open to exploring new social avenues, like local meetups or hobby groups?
Maybe. I’m not sure how comfortable I’d feel in a group.
That’s understandable. We can take it slow. How about just researching some options this week?
Yeah, I could do that.
Perfect! It’s all about taking small steps. So, what’s one thing you’re looking forward to this week?
Uh, I guess just trying to get back into drawing and listening to some new music.
That sounds like a good plan! I hope it brings you joy. Before we wrap up today, is there anything else you’d like to discuss?
Not really. I think we covered a lot.
I’m glad to hear that! Remember, it’s okay to take things one step at a time. I look forward to hearing about your drawing next time.
Yeah, me too. Thanks!
You’re welcome! See you next time!
Bye!
